newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: President asks Swiss to unite to restore image.
newsitem.headline: President asks Swiss to unite to restore image.

text.p: Swiss President Arnold Koller on Friday urged his citizens, torn by controversy over their country's role in World War Two, to rally behind efforts to repair Switzerland's standing.
Koller's speech was one of an estimated 3,000 by politicians, dignitaries and others on the Swiss national day, which commemorates the alliance between the first three Swiss cantons in 1291.

"Solidarity inside and outside the country is a duty which over time has become part of the concept of the Swiss nation, as much as our direct democracy, federalism or right to freedom," Koller said in his speech, broadcast on radio and television.

"We must also renew solidarity in order to once again secure Switzerland's humanitarian tradition in the world, and give it a new shine. We are especially in need of this, as a neutral small nation," Koller said.
The word "solidarity" carries extra resonance in Switzerland since the cabinet called in February for a seven billion franc ($4.6 billion) "Solidarity Foundation" to aid the needy at home and abroad.
The idea followed sharp foreign criticism of the country's World War Two role.
Documents recently released from U.S. archives have shone the international spotlight on Switzerland's wartime past.
Some Swiss industrialists aided the Nazis, while some banks kept accounts for Nazis, or failed to find assets left for safe-keeping during World War Two by Holocaust victims.
On Thursday, a U.S. court began hearings on whether Swiss banks could be liable to face class-action suits from Holocaust victims who said the banks stole their assets.
The latest criticism of Switzerland's wartime role has been led by international Jewish organisations and U.S. Senator Alfonse D'Amato.

Earlier this week, D'Amato demanded that the country's biggest bank, Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS), apologise to a former security guard who fled the country fearing for his safety after saving Holocaust-era documents from shredding at the bank.

Far-right politicians have used criticism of Switzerland to attract votes. Mainstream politicians in turn fear this could block approval of the Solidarity Foundation, to be funded from a revaluation of Swiss gold reserves.

Right-wing leader Christoph Blocher, who says the Foundation is akin to an admission of Swiss guilt, said in a speech on Thursday that Switzerland could go its own way without needing to isolate itself.
Some Swiss on Friday staged an "alternative" national day celebration, first begun by post-war Swiss authors Max Frisch, Friedrich Duerrenmatt and others.
Catholic priest Cornelius Koch, who led the celebration this year, warned that the divisions in the country could foster racism and xenophobia.
"The banks should stop using people and the government as hostages and finally face up to their guilt," he said in a speech.
"These public discussions about the past, which could be a thunderstorm that clears the air, are now being used by the extreme right and populists," he said. ($ = 1.516 Swiss Francs)
